Church IN Bremen.--A letter from the Reverend
Mr.. Kurtz, Lutheran minister now in Europe,
published in the New York Christian Advocate,
states that there is Lutheran Clutch at Bremen,
Germany, 800 feet long, Of proportionable width,
with seeple seven stories high. exclusive Of the
spire.--The congregation embrace, $4,000 souls.
and has four clergymen and one assistant. Tn
der the building is cellar in which arc mum.
ber OF dead bodies in state OF preservation, although
they have been deposited mere 900 years. with
my own eyes," says MIR. Kur,z," saw the bodies
in full as they we're centuries ago. The enuail.
are dried away, but the external parts are yet com.
plete and even the caps with which they were in


tered 200 years ago, and other parts Of the grave
clothes, are in state Of perfect preservation These
bodies are not mummies but are preserved ty the
peculiar nature OF the atmosphere,


Mr.. kustz says there is wine cellar in BIemer
containing some wine that IS several centuries old.

Monsters 0f HI. Sea.--The following stateme nj
i, commune a,ed 90 the editor OF the New York Eve
ming Post, by an acquaintance, who eil vouch
or its authenticity.


Erfract from The journal Of The snpercarso Of a


ressel recently returned from the Fast Indies.


"On our voyage out, in latitude 40, SOUTH longi
,ude about 90, east, we surrounded for several
hours BY number OF Sea Monsters, Of description
which neither the captain (who had been 10 sea Tor
20 years, aud or s voyages to lndia) nor any one
on board was acquainted with, or hsd ever seen.
They were species Of serpent and carried their
bead, three or tour feet out Of water their bodies
appeared OF an irregular shape. resembling sunk
en- rock, and were covered with barnacles their
tails were foiked like hsh's and very large. We
had very disinc, view OF two Of them which ap.
preached US from direction abeam ofus, and with
out apparently taking scarcely any notice os Us, pas
srd close under our bowsprt and TO avoid running
or them we we're obliged to keep the yes.e off, be-
ing fearful Of nuring her copper, They appear
ed TO be Thirty or forty feet in length, and at times
moved through the water With great celeii;y. Some
OF them 9, short distance Off exactly resembled
The representation, and their appearance generally
was similar to the description have seen oflhe Sea
Serpent, which appeared on our cost some time
since There were eight or ten Of them, and they
continued around US from noon, when they were
first seen, until dark

A NEW PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE"


The deep interest which many of our counirymen
feel in the welfare Of the people has induced many
OF them TO relinquish their ordinary pursuits 70
guard the public liberty.


So alarmed are the friends Of freedom for the
safety Of The Republic that, although the presiden
,ial election does not take place tor nearly TWO
years, they arc already, and long have been, on the
alert.


For my own part, am quite satisfied with our
present Chief Magistrate, though he may never
have sme gun powder.


have long thought, that, that wisdom IN Councn
which foresees and honotaby averts Il, is ever
more valuable Than that military prowess, which
conouers victory in the field. The former cost.
nothing-the latter is necessarily purchased st the
expense Of blood and treasure. But many OF our
coun,rymen consider that Military aurels arc indls
pensabe 10 civic honors.


II therefore il be necessary TO make change 10
our National Executive, let US award the highest
station to him, who contributed most TO conquer an
honorable peace.


Far be ii fiom me TO wish TO detract in the small
est degree from the well earned reputation OF Cen
cral Jackson. His Brilliant exploits have shed us
tre upon the Amer can name and character.


Blu, think i, would hr difficult to prove, that his
victory Al New Orleans, contributed III any manner TO
bring abou, the late peace with Great Britain.
BY reference TO the Treaty Of Ghent, il will be
found ,ha, il was signed on the 24th December,
l9li and il is scarcely necessary TO add, that Gen
Jackspn's victory obtained two weeks alter, or
the 9Th OF January, l8l5 at New Orleans, which IS
full four thousand miles from Ghent.
! The instructions from the British Government 10
their Commissioners at Ghent, mus, have been
transmitted to Them not later than in November OF
early in December, 1874.


The newa Of the victory al Orleans, reached En-
gland the beginning Of March, 1915.
4 The writer therefore, who can prove, that the
victory OF Orleans produced the peace Of Ghen
may not despair Of proving that Homer borrowed
lhs idea OF the Illisd from Pope. AS there is moth
4 ing in the Constitution OIL Laws Of the United States
which prohibits any citizen from nominating anoh
er, as public officer beg leave TO nominate


COMMODORE ISAAC HULL.
as suitable candidate for the office Of President oil
the United States /; provided il should be deemee
necessary to ii axe change in that Department.
4 Commodore Hull had the distinguished honor
receiving tho first British Naval Flag, surrendered
to an enemy Of inferior force.


Who does not recollect the important result.
which flowed from that victory?
4 Itrevived the dropping spirits ofIhe Nation, which
the repeated disasters Of our army in Canada hst
produced. Il doubtless laid the foundation for many
Of our subsequent victories the Lakes and .ht
Ocean, which materially contributed to bring
about an honorable peace.


u To the writer hereof, Commodore Hull is an en-
tire sranger.-He is only known to him by the
fame Of his leeds.-By the imperishabe renown he
acquired for himself and the Navy, and for the last
ing benefits be conferred upon beloved country


JOHN HANCOCK.
For the Democratic Press.

NO AN ACT for the relief OF the Indgent Sufferers


BY the fire al Alexandra.


Be il enacted by the Senate and Hous, Of hfpre.
spntatires Of the United States Of 7merica in Con-
rress assembled, That the sum Of twenty thousand
dollars be, ana the same is hereby approprlatedo oe
paid out Of any money in the Treasury not otherwise
appropriated for the relief Of the INDECENT sufferers
By the destructive FIRE in The City OF Alexandra, IN
the District OF Columbia, TO be distributed under the
direction Of The Mayor and Common Council Of the
City Of Alexandria, for the immediate relief OF such
class Of sufferers, and for no other purpose.


JOHN W. TAYLOR,


Speaker of the House of Representatives.


NATH'I. MACON,


President Of the Senate pro tempore.
Approved cath Jan. 1927

ed TO be Thirty or forty feet in length, and at times
moved through the water With great celeii;y. Some
OF them 9, short distance Off exactly resembled
The representation, and their appearance generally
was similar to the description have seen oflhe Sea
Serpent, which appeared on our cost some time
since There were eight or ten Of them, and they
continued around US from noon, when they were
first seen, until dark

full articles.headline: For the Democratic Press.
full articles.article:
A NEW PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE"


The deep interest which many of our counirymen
feel in the welfare Of the people has induced many
OF them TO relinquish their ordinary pursuits 70
guard the public liberty.


So alarmed are the friends Of freedom for the
safety Of The Republic that, although the presiden
,ial election does not take place tor nearly TWO
years, they arc already, and long have been, on the
alert.


For my own part, am quite satisfied with our
present Chief Magistrate, though he may never
have sme gun powder.


have long thought, that, that wisdom IN Councn
which foresees and honotaby averts Il, is ever
more valuable Than that military prowess, which
conouers victory in the field. The former cost.
nothing-the latter is necessarily purchased st the
expense Of blood and treasure. But many OF our
coun,rymen consider that Military aurels arc indls
pensabe 10 civic honors.


II therefore il be necessary TO make change 10
our National Executive, let US award the highest
station to him, who contributed most TO conquer an
honorable peace.


Far be ii fiom me TO wish TO detract in the small
est degree from the well earned reputation OF Cen
cral Jackson. His Brilliant exploits have shed us
tre upon the Amer can name and character.


Blu, think i, would hr difficult to prove, that his
victory Al New Orleans, contributed III any manner TO
bring abou, the late peace with Great Britain.
BY reference TO the Treaty Of Ghent, il will be
found ,ha, il was signed on the 24th December,
l9li and il is scarcely necessary TO add, that Gen
Jackspn's victory obtained two weeks alter, or
the 9Th OF January, l8l5 at New Orleans, which IS
full four thousand miles from Ghent.
! The instructions from the British Government 10
their Commissioners at Ghent, mus, have been
transmitted to Them not later than in November OF
early in December, 1874.


The newa Of the victory al Orleans, reached En-
gland the beginning Of March, 1915.
4 The writer therefore, who can prove, that the
victory OF Orleans produced the peace Of Ghen
may not despair Of proving that Homer borrowed
lhs idea OF the Illisd from Pope. AS there is moth
4 ing in the Constitution OIL Laws Of the United States
which prohibits any citizen from nominating anoh
er, as public officer beg leave TO nominate


COMMODORE ISAAC HULL.
as suitable candidate for the office Of President oil
the United States /; provided il should be deemee
necessary to ii axe change in that Department.
4 Commodore Hull had the distinguished honor
receiving tho first British Naval Flag, surrendered
to an enemy Of inferior force.


Who does not recollect the important result.
which flowed from that victory?
4 Itrevived the dropping spirits ofIhe Nation, which
the repeated disasters Of our army in Canada hst
produced. Il doubtless laid the foundation for many
Of our subsequent victories the Lakes and .ht
Ocean, which materially contributed to bring
about an honorable peace.


u To the writer hereof, Commodore Hull is an en-
tire sranger.-He is only known to him by the
fame Of his leeds.-By the imperishabe renown he
acquired for himself and the Navy, and for the last
ing benefits be conferred upon beloved country


JOHN HANCOCK.

NO AN ACT for the relief OF the Indgent Sufferers


BY the fire al Alexandra.


Be il enacted by the Senate and Hous, Of hfpre.
spntatires Of the United States Of 7merica in Con-
rress assembled, That the sum Of twenty thousand
dollars be, ana the same is hereby approprlatedo oe
paid out Of any money in the Treasury not otherwise
appropriated for the relief Of the INDECENT sufferers
By the destructive FIRE in The City OF Alexandra, IN
the District OF Columbia, TO be distributed under the
direction Of The Mayor and Common Council Of the
City Of Alexandria, for the immediate relief OF such
class Of sufferers, and for no other purpose.


JOHN W. TAYLOR,


Speaker of the House of Representatives.


NATH'I. MACON,


President Of the Senate pro tempore.
Approved cath Jan. 1927

he State Of Indiana, or his health being drunk he

As he had nothing to conceal with regard to his O.
